_header: Half in a dream not fully awaked
_description: ‘La Belle Dame sans Mercy’, perhaps by Sir Richard Roos, translated from Alain Chartier — 856 lines (including 4-stanza Envoy) in rhyme royal and 8-line stanzas

BodFair16.First Lines:
HAlffe in a dreme not fully wel awakydThe golden slepe me wrapt
                    vndir his wing…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…And in their trouth purpose hem to endureI pray god sende hem
                    bettir aventure
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
Balade de la bele Dame sanz mercy (f. 50v); Explicit
                        la bele dame sanz mercy (f. 62)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
BodFair16.Editions:
Skeat,  Walter William,
                        ed.  
             The Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer.
         7 vols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1894-7: 7.299.

CULFf16.First Lines:
Halfe in a dreme not fully well a wakedThe golden slepe me wrapt
                    vndir his wyng…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…And in þair trouth purpose hem to EndureI pray god sende
                    hem bettyr aventure
CULFf16.Attributed Title:
Chaucer La belle dame sans mercy (f. 117, post-medieval
                    hand)
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.
CULFf16.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: rev. ed. 80-111.
Gray,  Douglas. 
             The Oxford Book of Late Medieval Verse and Prose.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1985: 85-8.

CamTCC599.First Lines:
Halfe in a dreme nat fully well awakydThe goldyn slepe me wrappyd
                    vndyr hys wyng…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…And in theyre trowthe purpose theym to endureI pray god sende
                    hem bettyr Auenture
CamTCC599.Facsimiles:
Fletcher,  Bradford Y. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Trinity R.3.19. A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, 1987. 

Digital Facsimile of Trinity College Cambridge MS R.3.19.

BLAdd17492.First Lines:
O marble herte and yet more harde perdewych mercy may not perce for
                    no labor…
BLAdd17492.Last Lines:
…ryght as ye lyst yt be ryght so wyll Ito bynd myself were I
                    was at lyberty

BLHar372.First Lines:
[H]Alf in a dreme not fully weel a wakidthe golden sleep me wrapt
                    vndir his wieng…
BLHar372.Last Lines:
…And in there trouthe purpose hem to endureI praye god sende
                    hem better aventure
BLHar372.Attributed Title:
La belle dame sanz mercy translatid out of ffrenche by sir Richard
                    Ros (f. 61, in right margin beside first line, by original scribe);
                    speakers’ names, ‘La dame’ or ‘Lamant’ written in
                    outer margins beside alternating stanzas in the dialogue, and ‘Verba
                        Auctoris’ and ‘Verba translatoris’ on ff. 69
                    and 69v; after conclusion on f. 69v, original scribe has
                    written ‘Qui legit emendat scriptorem non
                    reprehendat’.
BLHar372.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 52-80.

Longleat258.First Lines:
[H]alf in a dreme nat fully wele awakedThe golden slepe me wrapt
                    vndre his whynge…
Longleat258.Last Lines:
…And in thair trouth purpose hem to endureI pray god sende hem
                    better aventure
Longleat258.Attributed Title: Here endith la bell / dame sanz mercy (f. 136v)
Longleat258.Editions:
Symons,  Dana M.,
                        ed.  
             Chaucerian Dream
                    Visions and Complaints.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 2004.
